**tl;dr: [My cost-split proposal](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/14i8b5Up2b4hVDre1hwOampszmgZMtLsEkogHt7qcm5Y/edit?gid=1703303946#gid=1703303946) is done — everyone saved money ($400 in total)! DM me your preferred payment method ([see options](https://discord.com/channels/900827411917201418/1285028917857488998/1285239608023711844)).**

It’s not required to understand the calculations in the sheet, but there are some details below.

**Details:**
The shipping costs for our order were more expensive than the total shipping costs would have been if we placed 22 separate orders. In this sense, we lost money on shipping. I calculated the shipping cost of the 22 individual orders to understand the exact loss.

The good news is we saved more with our 10% NS discount than we lost in shipping.

I’ve decided to cover our shipping losses with the discount. After this, our remaining discount is equivalent to a 5.5% discount on the whole order.

**The final result is equivalent to if everyone made their own order and got a 5.5% discount.**

With this approach, everyone saves money, everyone is accountable for what they would have paid in shipping on their own, and no one is disadvantaged for having made a larger or smaller order.

I considered alternative ways to split the costs. I’m happy to discuss them, but it would be quite a bit more work for me to lay out the considerations in a concise, clear way. So I’m going to forego that for now. I’m happy to answer specific questions.

An interesting side note — most of the blueprint product prices have changed by 1 - 4 MYR since we placed our order.

You get it in around 5 days or so, which is not that bad. However you can also get it done in less than 2 days through express mode (In India only and not from Singapore). Some travel companies have direct connection with the Singapore consulate here, so they can help you with the express process.

Malaysia Immigration/Customs (anecdote):

I'm a US Citizen.

I arrived by plane to Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia on Sunday. 

Where the online form asked for my onward ticket, I chose LAND and just put bus ticket a2345.

When immigration asked how long I'd stay, I told them I would stay 2 weeks because I plan to go Singapore by land for conference.

They said "okay 👍" and gave me a 90 day stamp.

They didn't actually care about an onward ticket. They gave me 90 days automatically, even with the assumption that I'd be leaving in 2 weeks.

I say that to say that it was very easy and hassle-free, they were welcoming.

YMMV, but if you were stressing about it, can relax. Just fill out your arrival info online anytime before walking up to immigration counter, preferably before flight

Just sharing my thoughts on the logistics of actually living in Forest City for up to 3 months (vs. just staying).
I expect a few things to be not be as streamlined as this has not been done before.

# Accommodation
Appears to be a hotel.

Pros: no need for cleaning, gym access, pool?
Cons: no amenities useful for longer stay (laundry, cooking / food storage)

Fine with me as included in the whole price and want to keep the team doing what they can. I expect to provide some additional budget to augment the experience.

# Food 
I've worked with a nutrionist for 3 months this year to get me ready for a sport event. Lost 14 kg while eating healthy and much more consistently.
Process included tracking everything I ate or cooked in myfitnesspal app to understand if I hit macros and calories. My fitness age is -5 years my biological age (Garmin watch data). Wasn't fun eating like this, but will do that again when at Network School (accountability buddies welcome).
I am not vegan but am looking forward to do the blue print experiment. Main concern is that I need my proteins and don't like to have them from powders.

# Laundry
If hotel laundry then pricey. Also prefer to have my own laundry vs. delegating that. Asia usually has good laundry services but I could not find any so far for Forest City.

Hi everyone

Wondering if anyone has stayed in Malaysia for almost a month, then traveled out for a weekend or so, and returned multiple times (3-4 consecutive stays on visa-free entry)? Simply put, has anyone done visa runs from Malaysia?

I lived in Singapore between 2009-2015, and back then, family & friends faced questioning when repeatedly entering/exiting SG on short-term visas, especially after doing quick turnarounds from a single country. Each entry granted a 30-day stay which could be extended up to 3 times, however frequent re-entries often led to scrutiny, particularly at land(Malaysia) and ferry(Indonesia) crossings. Also, after the 2/3 entry they were given a warning to return to their country by a certain date. 

Not sure if Malaysia has similar practices. I know it ultimately depends on the immigration officer, but I’d appreciate any insights or recent experiences with this.  Thanks

As @undefined shared in <#1278081815139188817> main channel, it's always helpful to have "proof of onward travel" when entering a country. It may not be asked for but if it is and you can't produce it, entry may be denied. 

Often, nomads and travelers book refundable tickets that can be cancelled later for free to show "exit ticket" in case it's requested at the port of entry.

Pro tip, buy your one-way onward travel flight on the same airline as the one you are checking into. That way they can see it in their system when you check in. Otherwise, your airline has to ask you for proof of onward travel and it is more of a process.
There are also sites like this that charge a small fee for proof of onward travel.
https://onwardticket.com/

Many countries do require "proof of onward travel" Often, they ask the airline you are flying with to check that you have proof of onward travel when you check in. 

I normally buy a fully refundable one-way ticket for proof of onward travel. When I arrive in the country I am traveling to and get through customs, then I cancel that onward travel. Expedia works well for this.
